backgroundInformationList.description: Notice of Intention to Remove a Holding Symbol (H) from Zoning By-law 794-2024 - 1 Sandfield Road

noticeDescription:
NOTICE OF INTENTION TO REMOVE A HOLDING SYMBOL (H) FROM ZONING BY-LAW 794-2024

(Under the Planning Act)

 

The City has received the following application under Section 36 of the Planning Act:

 

Application Number: 24 204488 NNY 15 OZ

Location of Application: 1 Sandfield Road

Ward: Ward 15 – Don Valley West

Contact: Rebecca Thompson, Planner, at 416-392-2535, by email at Rebecca.Thompson@toronto.ca or by mailing at North York Civic Centre, 5100 Yonge St., North York, ON, M2N5V7

 

DESCRIPTION

 

The application is to remove a holding symbol (H) for servicing related matters at 1 Sandfield Road   to permit the development of seven townhouses.  The holding symbol was enacted through Zoning By-law 569-2013, as amended by site specific By-law 794-2024. The area where the holding symbol (H) would be removed is noted on the map below.

 

Detailed information regarding the above-listed proposal, including background information and materials may be made available for public inspection by contacting the Planner noted above or by visiting the https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/planning-development/application-details/?id=5502269&pid=405598&title=1-SANDFIELD-RD.

 

MAKE YOUR VIEWS KNOWN

 

You may send written comments by mail or email to the Planner noted above. Your written comments must be submitted no later than November 01, 2024 to be considered by the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning or designate. A decision by the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning or designate as to whether to remove the holding symbol (H) will occur no earlier than November 19, 2024.

 

Notice to People Writing to the City: The City of Toronto Act, 2006, the Planning Act, and the City of Toronto Municipal Code authorize the City of Toronto to collect any personal information in your communication to the City.

 

The City collects this information to enable it to make informed decisions on the relevant issue(s).  If you are submitting letters, e-mails, or other communications to the City, you should be aware that your name and the fact that you communicated with the City will become part of the public record and will appear on the City's website. The City will also make your communication and any personal information in it - such as your postal address, telephone number or e-mail address - available to the public, unless you expressly request the City to remove it.
